dddd.name: NTKS
dddd.desc: rocks or mountain peaks protruding through glacial ice

dddd.name: PAN
dddd.desc: a near-level shallow, natural depression or basin, usually containing an intermittent lake, pond, or pool

dddd.name: PANS
dddd.desc: a near-level shallow, natural depression or basin, usually containing an intermittent lake, pond, or pool

dddd.name: PASS
dddd.desc: a break in a mountain range or other high obstruction, used for transportation from one side to the other [See also gap]

dddd.name: PEN
dddd.desc: an elongate area of land projecting into a body of water and nearly surrounded by water

dddd.name: PENX
dddd.desc: of peninsula

dddd.name: PK
dddd.desc: a pointed elevation atop a mountain, ridge, or other hypsographic feature

dddd.name: PKS
dddd.desc: pointed elevations atop a mountain, ridge, or other hypsographic features

dddd.name: PLAT
dddd.desc: an elevated plain with steep slopes on one or more sides, and often with incised streams

dddd.name: PLATX
dddd.desc: of plateau

dddd.name: PLDR
dddd.desc: an area reclaimed from the sea by diking and draining

dddd.name: PLN
dddd.desc: plain(s) an extensive area of comparatively level to gently undulating land, lacking surface irregularities, and usually adjacent to a higher area

dddd.name: PLNX
dddd.desc: of plain

dddd.name: PROM
dddd.desc: promontory(-ies) a bluff or prominent hill overlooking or projecting into a lowland

dddd.name: PT
dddd.desc: a tapering piece of land projecting into a body of water, less prominent than a cape

dddd.name: PTS
dddd.desc: tapering pieces of land projecting into a body of water, less prominent than a cape

dddd.name: RDGB
dddd.desc: ridge a ridge of sand just inland and parallel to the beach, usually in series

dddd.name: RDGE
dddd.desc: ridge(s) a long narrow elevation with steep sides, and a more or less continuous crest

dddd.name: REG
dddd.desc: desert a desert plain characterized by a surface veneer of gravel and stones

dddd.name: RK
dddd.desc: a conspicuous, isolated rocky mass

dddd.name: RKFL
dddd.desc: an irregular mass of fallen rock at the base of a cliff or steep slope

dddd.name: RKS
dddd.desc: conspicuous, isolated rocky masses

dddd.name: SAND
dddd.desc: area a tract of land covered with sand

dddd.name: SBED
dddd.desc: stream bed a channel formerly containing the water of a stream

dddd.name: SCRP
dddd.desc: a long line of cliffs or steep slopes separating level surfaces above and below

dddd.name: SDL
dddd.desc: a broad, open pass crossing a ridge or between hills or mountains

dddd.name: SHOR
dddd.desc: a narrow zone bordering a waterbody which covers and uncovers at high and low water, respectively

dddd.name: SINK
dddd.desc: a small crater-shape depression in a karst area

dddd.name: SLID
dddd.desc: a mound of earth material, at the base of a slope and the associated scoured area

dddd.name: SLP
dddd.desc: slope(s) a surface with a relatively uniform slope angle

dddd.name: SPIT
dddd.desc: a narrow, straight or curved continuation of a beach into a waterbody

dddd.name: SPUR
dddd.desc: spur(s) a subordinate ridge projecting outward from a hill, mountain or other elevation

dddd.name: TAL
dddd.desc: slope a steep concave slope formed by an accumulation of loose rock fragments at the base of a cliff or steep slope

dddd.name: TRGD
dddd.desc: trough(s) a long wind-swept trough between parallel longitudinal dunes

dddd.name: TRR
dddd.desc: a long, narrow alluvial platform bounded by steeper slopes above and below, usually overlooking a waterbody

dddd.name: UPLD
dddd.desc: an extensive interior region of high land with low to moderate surface relief

dddd.name: VAL
dddd.desc: an elongated depression usually traversed by a stream

dddd.name: VALG
dddd.desc: valley a valley the floor of which is notably higher than the valley or shore to which it leads; most common in areas that have been glaciated

dddd.name: VALS
dddd.desc: elongated depressions usually traversed by a stream

dddd.name: VALX
dddd.desc: of valley

dddd.name: VLC
dddd.desc: a conical elevation composed of volcanic materials with a crater at the top

dddd.name: APNU
dddd.desc: a gentle slope, with a generally smooth surface, particularly found around groups of islands and seamounts

dddd.name: ARCU
dddd.desc: a low bulge around the southeastern end of the island of Hawaii

dddd.name: ARRU
dddd.desc: an area of subdued corrugations off Baja California

dddd.name: BDLU
dddd.desc: a region adjacent to a continent, normally occupied by or bordering a shelf, that is highly irregular with depths well in excess of those typical of a shelf

dddd.name: BKSU
dddd.desc: elevations, typically located on a shelf, over which the depth of water is relatively shallow but sufficient for safe surface navigation

dddd.name: BNKU
dddd.desc: an elevation, typically located on a shelf, over which the depth of water is relatively shallow but sufficient for safe surface navigation

dddd.name: BSNU
dddd.desc: a depression more or less equidimensional in plan and of variable extent

dddd.name: CDAU
dddd.desc: an entire mountain system including the subordinate ranges, interior plateaus, and basins

dddd.name: CNSU
dddd.desc: relatively narrow, deep depressions with steep sides, the bottom of which generally has a continuous slope

dddd.name: CNYU
dddd.desc: a relatively narrow, deep depression with steep sides, the bottom of which generally has a continuous slope

dddd.name: CRSU
dddd.desc: rise a gentle slope rising from oceanic depths towards the foot of a continental slope

dddd.name: DEPU
dddd.desc: a localized deep area within the confines of a larger feature, such as a trough, basin or trench

dddd.name: EDGU
dddd.desc: edge a line along which there is a marked increase of slope at the outer margin of a continental shelf or island shelf

dddd.name: ESCU
dddd.desc: (or scarp) an elongated and comparatively steep slope separating flat or gently sloping areas

dddd.name: FANU
dddd.desc: a relatively smooth feature normally sloping away from the lower termination of a canyon or canyon system

dddd.name: FLTU
dddd.desc: a small level or nearly level area

dddd.name: FRZU
dddd.desc: zone an extensive linear zone of irregular topography of the sea floor, characterized by steep-sided or asymmetrical ridges, troughs, or escarpments

dddd.name: FURU
dddd.desc: a closed, linear, narrow, shallow depression

dddd.name: GAPU
dddd.desc: a narrow break in a ridge or rise

dddd.name: GLYU
dddd.desc: a small valley-like feature

dddd.name: HLLU
dddd.desc: an elevation rising generally less than 500 meters

dddd.name: HLSU
dddd.desc: elevations rising generally less than 500 meters

dddd.name: HOLU
dddd.desc: a small depression of the sea floor

dddd.name: KNLU
dddd.desc: an elevation rising generally more than 500 meters and less than 1,000 meters and of limited extent across the summit

dddd.name: KNSU
dddd.desc: elevations rising generally more than 500 meters and less than 1,000 meters and of limited extent across the summits

dddd.name: LDGU
dddd.desc: a rocky projection or outcrop, commonly linear and near shore

dddd.name: LEVU
dddd.desc: an embankment bordering a canyon, valley, or seachannel

dddd.name: MESU
dddd.desc: an isolated, extensive, flat-topped elevation on the shelf, with relatively steep sides

dddd.name: MNDU
dddd.desc: a low, isolated, rounded hill

dddd.name: MOTU
dddd.desc: an annular depression that may not be continuous, located at the base of many seamounts, islands, and other isolated elevations

dddd.name: MTU
dddd.desc: a well-delineated subdivision of a large and complex positive feature

dddd.name: PKSU
dddd.desc: prominent elevations, part of a larger feature, either pointed or of very limited extent across the summit

dddd.name: PKU
dddd.desc: a prominent elevation, part of a larger feature, either pointed or of very limited extent across the summit

dddd.name: PLNU
dddd.desc: a flat, gently sloping or nearly level region

dddd.name: PLTU
dddd.desc: a comparatively flat-topped feature of considerable extent, dropping off abruptly on one or more sides

dddd.name: PNLU
dddd.desc: a high tower or spire-shaped pillar of rock or coral, alone or cresting a summit

dddd.name: PRVU
dddd.desc: a region identifiable by a group of similar physiographic features whose characteristics are markedly in contrast with surrounding areas

dddd.name: RDGU
dddd.desc: a long narrow elevation with steep sides

dddd.name: RDSU
dddd.desc: long narrow elevations with steep sides

dddd.name: RFSU
dddd.desc: surface-navigation hazards composed of consolidated material

dddd.name: RFU
dddd.desc: a surface-navigation hazard composed of consolidated material

dddd.name: RISU
dddd.desc: a broad elevation that rises gently, and generally smoothly, from the sea floor

dddd.name: SCNU
dddd.desc: a continuously sloping, elongated depression commonly found in fans or plains and customarily bordered by levees on one or two sides

dddd.name: SCSU
dddd.desc: continuously sloping, elongated depressions commonly found in fans or plains and customarily bordered by levees on one or two sides

dddd.name: SDLU
dddd.desc: a low part, resembling in shape a saddle, in a ridge or between contiguous seamounts

dddd.name: SHFU
dddd.desc: a zone adjacent to a continent (or around an island) that extends from the low water line to a depth at which there is usually a marked increase of slope towards oceanic depths

dddd.name: SHLU
dddd.desc: a surface-navigation hazard composed of unconsolidated material

dddd.name: SHSU
dddd.desc: hazards to surface navigation composed of unconsolidated material

dddd.name: SHVU
dddd.desc: valley a valley on the shelf, generally the shoreward extension of a canyon

dddd.name: SILU
dddd.desc: the low part of a gap or saddle separating basins

dddd.name: SLPU
dddd.desc: the slope seaward from the shelf edge to the beginning of a continental rise or the point where there is a general reduction in slope

dddd.name: SMSU
dddd.desc: elevations rising generally more than 1,000 meters and of limited extent across the summit

dddd.name: SMU
dddd.desc: an elevation rising generally more than 1,000 meters and of limited extent across the summit

dddd.name: SPRU
dddd.desc: a subordinate elevation, ridge, or rise projecting outward from a larger feature

dddd.name: TERU
dddd.desc: a relatively flat horizontal or gently inclined surface, sometimes long and narrow, which is bounded by a steeper ascending slope on one side and by a steep descending slope on the opposite side

dddd.name: TMSU
dddd.desc: (or guyots) seamounts having a comparatively smooth, flat top

dddd.name: TMTU
dddd.desc: (or guyot) a seamount having a comparatively smooth, flat top

dddd.name: TNGU
dddd.desc: an elongate (tongue-like) extension of a flat sea floor into an adjacent higher feature

dddd.name: TRGU
dddd.desc: a long depression of the sea floor characteristically flat bottomed and steep sided, and normally shallower than a trench

dddd.name: TRNU
dddd.desc: a long, narrow, characteristically very deep and asymmetrical depression of the sea floor, with relatively steep sides

dddd.name: VALU
dddd.desc: a relatively shallow, wide depression, the bottom of which usually has a continuous gradient

dddd.name: VLSU
dddd.desc: a relatively shallow, wide depression, the bottom of which usually has a continuous gradient

dddd.name: BUSH
dddd.desc: bush(es) a small clump of conspicuous bushes in an otherwise bare area

dddd.name: CULT
dddd.desc: area an area under cultivation

dddd.name: FRST
dddd.desc: forest(s) an area dominated by tree vegetation

dddd.name: FRSTF
dddd.desc: forest a forest fossilized by geologic processes and now exposed at the earth's surface

dddd.name: GRSLD
dddd.desc: an area dominated by grass vegetation

dddd.name: GRVC
dddd.desc: grove a planting of coconut trees

dddd.name: GRVO
dddd.desc: grove a planting of olive trees

dddd.name: GRVP
dddd.desc: grove a planting of palm trees

dddd.name: GRVPN
dddd.desc: grove a planting of pine trees

dddd.name: HTH
dddd.desc: an upland moor or sandy area dominated by low shrubby vegetation including heather

dddd.name: MDW
dddd.desc: a small, poorly drained area dominated by grassy vegetation

dddd.name: OCH
dddd.desc: orchard(s) a planting of fruit or nut trees

dddd.name: SCRB
dddd.desc: an area of low trees, bushes, and shrubs stunted by some environmental limitation

dddd.name: TREE
dddd.desc: tree(s) a conspicuous tree used as a landmark

dddd.name: TUND
dddd.desc: a marshy, treeless, high latitude plain, dominated by mosses, lichens, and low shrub vegetation under permafrost conditions

dddd.name: VIN
dddd.desc: a planting of grapevines

dddd.name: VINS
dddd.desc: plantings of grapevines
